I've been using a clamp light with LED bulb and parchment paper diffuser for WebEx conferences during work-from-home. An old desk lamp bounced off a wall on my other side adds a fill light.
One thing to note: if you do use incandescent/halogen as mentioned, they will get quite hot and wax paper may not be the best diffuser depending on how close to the bulb you attach it. Parchment paper for cooking works just as well and it's meant to withstand oven temps so as long as it's not sitting directly on a hot halogen for extended periods it may be preferable to wax paper.
Also, if you're more concerned with conferencing than streaming, a headset (even the old wired cell phone one you had from before OEMs lost their collective mind) will make a huge difference in avoiding background noise and preventing echo in conferences. People who use laptop mic/speakers are the bane of my existence and even for recording or streaming a headset mic has a better pickup pattern than the one on your phone, webcam, or laptop.

- In IP Webcam settings, set Video Prefs->Video Recording->Format to MP4 to activate hardware video encoding acceleration (it's not default because on low-quality firmware using it might lead to instability).
- Instead of OBS->Browser Source use OBS->Video Source, and set the source to rtsp://your_ip:port/h264_opus.sdp
- Decrease Network Caching to the minimum your network allows.

This is excluding the PC, the most important part of streaming. You could go low end, 30fps stream at 720p or lower, and get an ok stream and gameplay. You could go higher, at the cost of lower quality stream or gameplay (ironic.) You could upgrade your PC, getting a higher quality gameplay, stream, or both. The higher quality you go, the more RAM, CPU, GPU (depending on codec), and network up bandwidth you will need. Thing is, finding "min specs" for a stream in x game with y fps and z resolution isn't really easy to find. So generally, you would want at least 16 gb RAM, more if you are playing high AAA games or streaming high resolutions/fps; a CPU with lots of cores (the more you have, the less lag or stutters you will see in your game. Also important if you aren't using GPU encoding [x264]); a network connection with at least 10 Mbps upload (most streams are less than this, but with a smaller connection you risk latency issues and dropped packets); a GPU with a supported encoder (GPU encoding is similar/less in load compared to a CPU encoder, mainly with the advantage of less CPU load and little loss in GPU quality. Generally something mid-tier and recent is the best band-for-buck option.)

Alternatively, you could use a second computer, putting less load on your gameplay, at the cost of more complicated setup (especially with audio- how to get your audio from your main computer to secondary computer and your headphones, all with minimizing latency?) (Speaking of audio, my own audio setup is complex and I hope to make a video about how it works and why I did it). For a 2nd full dedicsted PC, you can go a little less on some things, but not everything. Go with a CPU with integrated graphics and no GPU, you will probably be fine using x264. Or, go with a low/mid GPU and CPU and you will probably be a bit better off. 16 gb RAM should be good enough for anything as long as the computer is dedicated to streaming. A high up network bandwidth is still necessary. You will also need a capture card or none of it will work.

This is the bulk of good streams. Sure you could just stream from your phone if you choose. But if you're going to put the effort to make a pro-looking stream setup, you should be using a pro-like PC to run it all. Or, you can forget about this video, and provide high quality livestreams of gameplay with no webcam or mic (or low quality such). As long as the content is interesting, I'd say you would be fine.

Note: I do livestream and make videos, however not with the intent to make profit off of such. But that intent does not stop me from trying to make the best quality content I can. Even with an expensive setup, you can still mess up, but don't let that stop you.

As someone who has spent WAY more time figuring out how to this perfectly, I have a way more nuanced opinion on how to do all this than Linus and his team. IPWebcam is the kind of strategy you pursue after some googling. But the latency and quality is shit.

Here's what you should actually do. Get out your usb cable, enable developer mode on your android and enable adb debugging. Then download droidcam x on both your PC and android and follow the instructions. The camera from your phone will show up as a webcam on your PC. This setup has the following advantages:
- charges your phone sufficiently even with the 500 mA port on your PC.
- you get FullHD video and audio from your phone's camera (either rear or front) if you buy or steal the pro version. Free version is 720p and sufficient too.
- you get the lowest possible latency. Low enough to not be bothered with syncing issues between the phone's video and your PC audio.
- you get camera controls on your PC for focusing, digital zoom.
- The screen brightness on your phone turns down to its lowest settings which conserves power
- It works reliably without bugs, is quick to turn on, tested by myself through many multi-hours sessions. Even the least tech-savvy person can do this.

The only viable alternative (if you don't need your phone's mic input) is scrcpy. But that is more complicated to set up, will not show up like a webcam on your PC and will just mirror your phone screen including all On-Screen information. Just don't do it if you want a webcam.

Instead of IP webcam use the obs.ninja website... just open it on your phone and add the generated link as a browser source on OBS to receive the feed. Once you get some money you can upgrade to a used DSLR (like a canon t3i and get the feed using the usb cable and Canon Webcam Utility, and later you can get a HDMI USB capture card to improve quality even more).
Instead of old lights that are oftenly not lit enough or dont have great light colors, use cheap chinese surface mount LED ceiling lights on the daylight color. They are soooo cheap, have some diffusion (makes shadows less aparent), dont heat as much and are thin (easier to setup than a light box).
Also I would never consider a condenser microphone a good option for a new streamer, since it captures too much ambient noise and we usually dont have controlled ambients. Instead consider buying a cheap dynamic microphone, like the Samson Q2u. It has both USB and XLR outputs, so at first you can use it standalone as a USB mic, and once you get some money you can invest on an audio interface and use the XLR output for better quality.

What kind of internet to get is too complex a question for this type of video, it depends on how many people are using the network, what kind of quality you want, and what's available in your particular situation. In our case we live in a condo and the best options available for internet are not all that great because even if we paid for a higher tier we basically bandwidth share with everyone in the complex plus a ton of fast food restaurants that are almost certainly on the same cable networks (with cable and phone internet you actually share with everyone on the same main cable or phone line as you). We also don't have the option for fiber here (fiber is faster and more direct which reduces latency but it requires fiber network lines which are often unavailable for condo/apartment buildings).

Capture cards are also complex because it depends on what you're capturing, what kind of OS support you need, and what quality you're willing to put up with. Easy cap can do 480p from composite or a little bit higher from S-Video but getting it to work on Windows 10 involves buying the unit (my brother got his years ago and just never set it up), finding out what the actual hardware for the unit is (there's like 10 different variations), and finding (if you're lucky) compatible firmware.
